[01-Jun-2007 12:21:27]  <hspcd> hi folks
[01-Jun-2007 12:26:35]  <bendsu> hellos
[01-Jun-2007 12:27:02]  *** cote has quit IRC
[01-Jun-2007 12:29:09] <hspcd> is it possible to use Zenoss to check a URL that requires login and then run a database query? We have a web application that is based on LAMP and this functionality from Zenoss would be huge, especially if the response times can be graphed.
[01-Jun-2007 12:30:28]  <davetoo> nagios-format plugin
[01-Jun-2007 12:30:50]  <hspcd> meaning?
[01-Jun-2007 12:31:23] <davetoo> Zenoss can use nagios plugins, and you can write your own tool that outputs the standard nagios-plugin format
[01-Jun-2007 12:32:28] <davetoo> so any other script (shell, perl, whatever) can be used as a DataSource in a performance template
[01-Jun-2007 12:33:44] <hspcd> so does this mean that we would be able to login over http/s and perform a db query, plus graph the response times?
[01-Jun-2007 12:35:01] <davetoo> Yes; you'd have to write a standalone tool that does the login and time measurement, and then outputs the standard one-line nagios output format
[01-Jun-2007 12:35:48] <davetoo> Search the zenoss community site for "nagios plugin"; it's also mentioned in the admin guide. You'll need to look at the Nagios Plugin Developer's stuff...
[01-Jun-2007 12:35:59]  <davetoo> I don't have links handy
[01-Jun-2007 12:36:10]  *** cote has joined #zenoss
[01-Jun-2007 12:36:21]  <davetoo> what I *don't* know is how you'd pass authentication info into your script.
[01-Jun-2007 12:36:35]  <davetoo> Haven't got that far yet, myself.
[01-Jun-2007 12:36:55]  * davetoo wanders away to get ready for work
[01-Jun-2007 12:38:44]  *** em-dash has joined #zenoss

[03-Jun-2007 16:54:16]  <bzed> Special Instructions After Source Install
[03-Jun-2007 16:54:16]  <bzed> =======================================================
[03-Jun-2007 16:54:16] <bzed> Builds from source will need to set the permissions on zensocket. To make this change, use the following command:
[03-Jun-2007 16:54:16]  <bzed> su root -c "chown root $ZENHOME/bin/zensocket; chmod uog+rx,u+ws $ZENHOME/bin/zensocket"
[03-Jun-2007 16:54:37]  *** cote has quit IRC
[03-Jun-2007 16:57:04]  <nassy> thanks. i am using the virtual machine. does that still apply
[03-Jun-2007 17:02:29]  *** cote has joined #zenoss

[03-Jun-2007 17:13:53]  <davetoo> You've made id SUID-zenoss
[03-Jun-2007 17:13:57]  <davetoo> which wont' help
[03-Jun-2007 17:14:08]  <davetoo> "root" needs to be the owner of zensocket
[03-Jun-2007 17:19:37]  <nassy> ah
[03-Jun-2007 17:22:34] <nassy> does the group matter. i now have rwsr-xr-x 1 root zenoss ... /home/zenoss/bin/zensocket but still get the same error
[03-Jun-2007 17:22:43]  <nassy> when i type zenoss start

[03-Jun-2007 20:55:21]  <|cyn|> hey all, i am running zenoss 1.1.1 and i want to get a report of service availability
[03-Jun-2007 20:55:40]  <|cyn|> every service seems to show 100% even if it has been down for some time.

[03-Jun-2007 21:04:08]  *** spekul has quit IRC
[03-Jun-2007 21:21:20]  <cluther_> |cyn|: Which report are you running?

[03-Jun-2007 21:23:17]  <|cyn|> this seems to default to 100.000% availability if it gets confused.
[03-Jun-2007 21:37:34]  *** chairuou|work has quit IRC
[03-Jun-2007 21:51:18] <cluther_> The default state is available. So if it can't find any events matching the event class and component selected it will report 100% available.
[03-Jun-2007 21:51:30]  <cluther_> What parameters are you requesting?
[03-Jun-2007 21:55:25]  *** chairuou|work has joined #zenoss
[03-Jun-2007 22:00:48]  <|cyn|> i am trying to check /status/ipservice for the period.

[03-Jun-2007 22:03:36]  *** indradg has quit IRC

[03-Jun-2007 22:14:16] <|cyn|> If i down a service on a host, then enter this hostname under device, the service name under component and /status/ipservice under event class, it gives me 100% even though this service has been downed for at least an hour a couple of times today.
[03-Jun-2007 22:14:39]  <cluther_> Do you get an event that it is down? Is the service set to be monitored?
[03-Jun-2007 22:14:57] <cluther_> The availability report is completely driven from events. Without an event it knows nothing.
[03-Jun-2007 22:15:48]  <|cyn|> yeah, i get an event on the service.
[03-Jun-2007 22:16:01]  <|cyn|> well, technically i get two. one that it is down, and one when it comes back up.

[04-Jun-2007 18:56:58] <andrew_p> bzed: i don't think so.. i get this problem every time i install zenoss (i was evaluating different versions of the same box) and after 5-10 attempts & guesses finally get it working without installing additional ports ok, i will document the solution for myself this time once i have found it
[04-Jun-2007 18:58:07]  <bzed> well
[04-Jun-2007 18:58:20]  <bzed> configure tries to link libld
[04-Jun-2007 18:58:28]  <bzed> that's part of libc6
[04-Jun-2007 18:58:46]  <bzed> not sure what freebsd usus as libc... never used it
[04-Jun-2007 18:59:04]  <bzed> have a look into /lib if there's a libdl*
[04-Jun-2007 19:22:50]  <andrew_p> bzed: thank you
[04-Jun-2007 19:25:49]  <cluther_> andrew_p: You shouldn't need to link to libdl at all in FreeBSD.
[04-Jun-2007 19:26:02]  <cluther_> Try taking -ldl off the end of the LIBS = line in the Makefile.
[04-Jun-2007 19:27:27]  <bzed> there shouldn;t be a makefile, as it's created by configure
[04-Jun-2007 19:27:33] <cluther_> davetoo: Still around? The purpose of that template is to keep track of per-process values for [cpu,mem,count]
[04-Jun-2007 19:27:42]  <bzed> configure should be able to figure out how to link it correcly
[04-Jun-2007 19:27:59]  <cluther_> bzed: I agree, but sometimes should and does don't get along.
[04-Jun-2007 19:28:36]  <bzed> yeah, but if it fails, there's no Makefile
[04-Jun-2007 19:28:42]  <bzed> autoconf sucks
[04-Jun-2007 19:28:53]  <cluther_> bzed: Bah.. I should go home.
[04-Jun-2007 19:30:12]  <bzed> andrew_p: try --with-gnu-ld as option to configure

[05-Jun-2007 15:17:19]  *** davetoo has joined #zenoss
[05-Jun-2007 15:17:29]  <davetoo> hi
[05-Jun-2007 15:19:48] <davetoo> cluther: I saw your response here yesterday; what I'm asking is ... the OSProcesses template seems incomplete. The DataSources contain no SNMP OIDs.
[05-Jun-2007 15:19:59]  <davetoo> Is it designed to be mixed-in with the Device template?
[05-Jun-2007 15:21:39]  *** Aziraphale has joined #zenoss
[05-Jun-2007 15:21:40] <cluther> Not really. It is special in that the zenprocess daemon handles it specifically. Not the zenperfsnmp daemon that handles general OID collection.
[05-Jun-2007 15:23:11] <cluther> enots: The fellow that handles that is aware of it, but he's been really wrapped up getting ready for the 2.0 release. It should be fixed this week or next.
[05-Jun-2007 15:23:36]  <davetoo> ok
[05-Jun-2007 15:26:57] <davetoo> But now I'm confused about monitoring specific processes to make sure they're running, vs. getting a running count (rrd) of number of processes running.
[05-Jun-2007 15:27:25]  <davetoo> In /Processes I can configure certain process names to be watched for
[05-Jun-2007 15:28:38] <cluther> ok, anytime you monitor a process it automatically applies the OSProcess template to it, thus creating the "count" data source.
[05-Jun-2007 15:29:09] <cluther> You can define that a process should be monitored or not at the global level in /Processes, then override the default behavior per device if you wish.
[05-Jun-2007 15:30:09] <davetoo> OK, so if what I really want is a count of the number of all processes of any kind running on a machine, I should add that to the Devices template or some other mix-in, I guess.
[05-Jun-2007 15:30:42]  <cluther> Exactly.

[06-Jun-2007 18:45:13] <chipig> I guess it wouldn't be too hard to write my own damon in python.. which would receive events from a properitary system.
[06-Jun-2007 18:45:48]  <creiht> How does the proprietary system send events?
[06-Jun-2007 18:46:01]  <chipig> custom stuff over sockets.
[06-Jun-2007 18:46:04]  <creiht> ahh
[06-Jun-2007 18:46:05]  <creiht> hmm
[06-Jun-2007 18:46:16]  <chipig> i have a swig binding into a C++ so i can call into it from python
[06-Jun-2007 18:46:26]  <creiht> That sounds best
[06-Jun-2007 18:46:32]  <creiht> just fyi
[06-Jun-2007 18:46:41]  <creiht> the other ways that you can get events into zenoss are
[06-Jun-2007 18:46:44]  <creiht> through syslog
[06-Jun-2007 18:46:51]  <creiht> and snmp traps
[06-Jun-2007 18:47:02]  <chipig> ya.. snmp traps would be the other way to consider.
[06-Jun-2007 18:47:17]  <chipig> but then there is another dependency, another protocol change
[06-Jun-2007 18:47:23]  <chipig> i like to keep those to a minimum
[06-Jun-2007 18:47:31]  <creiht> makes sense
[06-Jun-2007 18:47:42]  <creiht> xmlrpc in python is very easy
[06-Jun-2007 18:48:01]  <creiht> actually xmlrpc in most dynamic languages is very easy

[06-Jun-2007 18:48:16]  <creiht> yeah
[06-Jun-2007 18:48:32]  <creiht> xmlrpc in C++ or Java, or anything Microsoft for that matter is a pain

[12-Jun-2007 16:20:59] <J-Bob> jmizell: AIX and HPUX are both tricky. They both have base agents with additional agents for things like host resources (CPU / Disk / Memory). There are good resources out there for configuring the AIX subagents. HPUX requires their extensible agent in addition to what ships with the base OS

[14-Jun-2007 13:25:59] <cluther_> andrew_p: Have you looked at the Admin Guide? There is a chapter in there on Alerting Rules.
[14-Jun-2007 13:27:11] <andrew_p> cluther_: yes, but i need rather an insight on setting up the event monitoring. Admin Guide is not very clear about that. i created several ip services and os processes to monitor, defined alerting rules. still not getting any alerts
[14-Jun-2007 13:28:02]  <cluther_> Check the zenactions log file. It will tell you if it is trying to send the alerts.
[14-Jun-2007 13:28:20] <andrew_p> then i mapped EventClass'es i am interested in to defaultmapping and sketched a text message for this default mapping - no luck.. do i need to create an event instance for the device somehow?
[14-Jun-2007 13:28:29]  <andrew_p> cluther_: ok...
[14-Jun-2007 13:28:51] <cluther_> I think the most common problem is that Zenoss tries to send the emails and they get rejected by the mail server due to an invalid sender address.
[14-Jun-2007 13:29:54]  <andrew_p> cluther_: it sends a test email well...
[14-Jun-2007 13:30:20]  <cluther_> ok, that's a good sign.
[14-Jun-2007 13:30:29] <andrew_p> cluther_: in zenactions.log there all records are saying "processed 0 rules" or "processed 0 commands"
[14-Jun-2007 13:30:31]  *** crazyal has quit IRC
[14-Jun-2007 13:30:34]  <cluther_> So these events aren't even showing up in the event console?
[14-Jun-2007 13:30:43]  <andrew_p> cluther_: they do show up
[14-Jun-2007 13:30:47]  <cluther_> Ok,, good..
[14-Jun-2007 13:30:59]  <cluther_> The real key here is the "processed 0 rules"
[14-Jun-2007 13:31:26] <cluther_> For some reason it isn't even processing the alerting rules you've created. I hate asking this question, but did you set the "Enabled" = True?
[14-Jun-2007 13:32:18] <andrew_p> cluther_: yes. Delay (secs) = 0, Enabled = True, Action = email, where Severity >= Info and Production State = Production
[14-Jun-2007 13:32:33] <cluther_> Try restarting the zenactions daemon, then look to see if it processes more than 0 rules.
[14-Jun-2007 13:37:07] <andrew_p> cluther_: still zero. in past, i tried restarting all daemons and it did not change anything
[14-Jun-2007 13:37:53]  <cluther_> Doh.. I always forget about this one little tid bit.
[14-Jun-2007 13:38:17] <cluther_> alerting rules for the default admin user aren't used. Create an actual user and put the alerting rules on it.
[14-Jun-2007 13:38:36]  <andrew_p> cluther_: haha.. great, thanks
[14-Jun-2007 13:38:42]  <andrew_p> i think i had this idea in the past...
[14-Jun-2007 13:44:30]  <andrew_p> it's a different pair of shoes what are event mappings for in a few words?
[14-Jun-2007 13:53:59] <cluther_> andrew_p: dressing up events to make them more appropriate, whatever your definition of that is.
[14-Jun-2007 13:54:51] <cluther_> At the most simple level, your move the events to different classes so instead of being /Unknown they are /Net/Link..
[14-Jun-2007 13:55:00]  <andrew_p> cluther_: ok, thanks
[14-Jun-2007 13:55:32] <cluther_> cluther_: You can change anything about an event, the text that is displayed, the severity, or arbitrary attributes. You can even change the deduplication behavior if you'd like to combine multiple events into one.
[14-Jun-2007 13:56:01] <rkagin> To anyone who can help me: I'm currently going to the zenoss code learning more about how zenoss monitors devices; where in the code does it determine what type of device it is and thus what sort of checks it does (i.e. where does the code delineate between routers, switches, servers, etc.)?
[14-Jun-2007 14:01:01]  <andrew_p> rkagin: does it?
[14-Jun-2007 14:01:43] <cluther_> rkagin: It is based upon the performance templates that are assigned to an object's device class, or the device itself.
[14-Jun-2007 14:02:29] <andrew_p> rkagin: yep. it comes with hardcoded templates, lets you define your own, but does not have the intelligence you mean
[14-Jun-2007 14:04:02] <rkagin> I guess I was under the impression that certain data was collected from certain devices depending on their type. The hardcoded templates - where are they located in the code? I'm perusing zenoss's trac now.
[14-Jun-2007 14:04:54] <cluther_> The templates aren't in the code. They are in the object database. The class they instantiate from the code is RRDTemplate
[14-Jun-2007 14:05:13]  <cluther_> Should be in Products/ZenModel
[14-Jun-2007 14:06:45] <rkagin> cluther_: Thanks. And then I assume the MIBs are the ones setup in $ZENHOME/share/snmp/mibs ?
[14-Jun-2007 14:07:16] <cluther_> rkagin: When you run zenmib, it imports any MIBs under $ZENHOME/share/mibs that weren't previously imported.
[14-Jun-2007 14:09:18] <rkagin> cluther_: Ok. And then the templates in the database created for different types of devices choose certain MIBs to monitor?
[14-Jun-2007 14:09:35]  <rkagin> [provided that different templates were created for different types of devices]
[14-Jun-2007 14:09:55] <cluther_> rkagin: Actually, MIBs and templates aren't linked in any way. MIBs are only used for translated SNMP traps into english.
[14-Jun-2007 14:10:09]  <cluther_> rkagin: The raw OIDs are used inside the template definitions.
[14-Jun-2007 14:10:57]  *** Bulwinkle has quit IRC
[14-Jun-2007 14:12:12] <rkagin> cluther_: I guess my knowledge from reading up on the code is more limited than I thought. All MIBs enabled then are used for all devices, or is there a preference that you can choose which MIBs are used to translate certain traps (or is there a preference that allows you to choose which traps are generated for which type of devices)?

[14-Jun-2007 14:30:11]  *** hotgrits has joined #zenoss
[14-Jun-2007 14:55:15]  *** hotgrits has quit IRC
[14-Jun-2007 15:16:29]  *** fishstickz has joined #zenoss
[14-Jun-2007 15:16:46]  *** cluther has joined #zenoss
[14-Jun-2007 15:22:43]  *** fishstickz_ has quit IRC
[14-Jun-2007 15:23:10]  <qru> Should the discovery of a /24 take hours with maybe 50 devices (routers) on the network?
[14-Jun-2007 15:24:55]  *** cluther_ has quit IRC
[14-Jun-2007 15:46:10] <rkagin> I've been looking around in code and in the forums - I thought there was a difference in the way routers vs. servers vs. switches were monitored, but I can't seem to find anything that indicates this. If there are differences, where are these?
[14-Jun-2007 15:57:36]  <cluther> qru: Definitely not. Do these routers have full BGP views?
[14-Jun-2007 15:58:50] <cluther> rkagin: Things are monitored depending on what components are discovered on them, and depending on what performance templates are applied to these components.. an example..
[14-Jun-2007 15:59:20] <cluther> rkagin: You have a Cisco router.. after Zenoss discovers it, you move it to the /Devices/Network/Router/Cisco device class.
[14-Jun-2007 16:00:05] <cluther> The zProperties of /Devices/Network/Router/Cisco say that Interfaces and Routes should be modeled on them. (zCollectorPlugins)
[14-Jun-2007 16:00:25] <cluther> So the Zenoss CMDB (configuration management database) learns about all of the interfaces and routes.
[14-Jun-2007 16:00:37]  <cluther> Routes can't really be monitored, so they're only stored as configuration information.
[14-Jun-2007 16:01:22]  <Aziraphale> cluther: they will if I ever get around to writing my bgpmib-2 plugin
[14-Jun-2007 16:05:48] <cluther> Interfaces automatically get the ethernetCsmacd applied to them, which will monitor throughput, packets and errors.
[14-Jun-2007 16:06:24]  <cluther> Aziraphale: What do you want it to do?
[14-Jun-2007 16:06:49]  <cluther> I'm only half here.. so please pardon my unresponsiveness.
[14-Jun-2007 16:07:20]  <Aziraphale> cluther: collect BGP peers and stats (prefixes received/accepted/rejected) for them
[14-Jun-2007 16:07:35]  *** bandinia has quit IRC
[14-Jun-2007 16:07:48]  <cluther> Aziraphale: That would be really cool... hmm.
[14-Jun-2007 16:08:36] <Aziraphale> structure of the mib is similar to the way interfaces are handled, so was thinking of adapting InterfaceMap
[14-Jun-2007 16:08:55]  <cluther> Aziraphale: I've built a couple of things that fit that mold.. dhcp pools, mail queues..
[14-Jun-2007 16:09:04]  <Aziraphale> need the collector plugin howto, though
[14-Jun-2007 16:09:10]  <cluther> Aziraphale: How's your zenfu?

[14-Jun-2007 16:18:43]  *** fishstickz has quit IRC
[14-Jun-2007 16:19:06] <rkagin> cluther: Sorry for the delay - was looking through other code and trying to understand things better. So essentially the zproperties of each category (i.e. Network/Router/Cisco/) determine what is monitored? What's the file that parses the zproperties of the category and does the checks every few minutes (and I assume zentrap.py collects the traps as a result of these tests)?
[14-Jun-2007 16:19:20]  <cluther> Aziraphale: Might be hard for me to test it..
[14-Jun-2007 16:19:45]  <Aziraphale> cluther: also not the best example for a doc seeing as it's so specialist
[14-Jun-2007 16:19:59]  <qru> cluther: No BGP. EIGRP.
[14-Jun-2007 16:20:20]  <Aziraphale> somebody actually uses that?
[14-Jun-2007 16:20:36] <cluther> rkagin: Separate modeling and monitoring from each other in your thoughts. the zCollectorPlugins determine what aspects of a device get modeled. The templates determine what aspects get monitored.
[14-Jun-2007 16:20:45]  <cluther> Aziraphale: heh.. you'd be surprised.
[14-Jun-2007 16:23:03]  <Aziraphale> cluther: don't think I've ever seen a live instance of EIGRP
[14-Jun-2007 16:23:09] <rkagin> cluther: Ok, so once a device is fully modeled, service checks get sent out every few minutes (which checks are determined by the template for the category) and the resulting traps get picked up by zentrap.py (?). Is the template actually sending out the pings to determine up/down time, CPU use, memory use, temperature, or whatever other characteristics are being monitored? Or is there something else I'm missing?
[14-Jun-2007 16:23:40]  <Aziraphale> most of the networks I work on are far to heterogenous
[14-Jun-2007 16:23:43]  <cluther> rkagin: This is basically the breakdown..
[14-Jun-2007 16:23:54]  <cluther> rkagin: zenperfsnmp monitors SNMP data sources defined in templates.
[14-Jun-2007 16:24:03]  <cluther> rkagin: zencommand monitors COMMAND data sources defined in templates.
[14-Jun-2007 16:24:49]  <cluther> rkagin: zenprocess monitors data sources defined in the OSProcess template specifically.
[14-Jun-2007 16:25:01]  <cluther> rkagin: zenping just pings everything's manageIp
[14-Jun-2007 16:25:26] <cluther> rkagin: zenstatus runs TCP connectivity tests on IpServices (listed on OS tab) that have monitored = True.
[14-Jun-2007 16:25:36]  <cluther> rkagin: zentrap listens passively for SNMP traps and converts them into events.
[14-Jun-2007 16:25:51] <cluther> rkagin: zensyslog listens passively for syslog messages (514/udp) and converts them into events.
[14-Jun-2007 16:26:19]  <cluther> Those are the key processes.. I've left the Windows WMI stuff out..
[14-Jun-2007 16:26:24] <rkagin> cluther: Gosh, I feel silly, because I have most of those files open and have perused through them at length, but I guess I just never got the stand-back picture.
[14-Jun-2007 16:27:07]  <cluther> rkagin: It's one of those eureka! kind of things.. it will come to you. =}
[14-Jun-2007 16:27:51] <rkagin> cluther: In terms of each of these different tests, the instantiated RRDTemplate dictates which of these processes need to collect data for the device? And do any of these different tests delineate between different types of devices (i.e. routers or servers), or do they simply identify them as an object/device?
[14-Jun-2007 16:28:56] <cluther> rkagin: Each process cares only about its specialty.. none of them know the difference between a server and a router really. They go into the database and ask for information they care about.. for example..
[14-Jun-2007 16:29:22]  <rkagin> cluther: [that's what I thought/understood, but please continue]
[14-Jun-2007 16:29:35] <cluther> rkagin: zenperfsnmp asks zenhub, "Hey, give me a list of all of the OIDs that are defined and the devices they're defined on."
[14-Jun-2007 16:29:39]  *** J-Bob has joined #zenoss
[14-Jun-2007 16:29:50]  <cluther> cluther: Because all zenperfsnmp cares about are OIDs..
[14-Jun-2007 16:30:41]  <cluther> talking to myself again..
[14-Jun-2007 16:31:09]  <J-Bob> cluther: bad sign =(
[14-Jun-2007 16:31:18] <cluther> rkagin: zenprocess asks zenhub for all devices and processes that have monitor = true. It then tries to pull everything in the OSProcess template for every single one of these.
[14-Jun-2007 16:34:42] <rkagin> cluther: I feel like I was looking for a red herring and totally missed the cooperation between files within the unified model. The intervals for each different test (depending on whether the test succeeded or not) are hard-coded in each test, right?
[14-Jun-2007 16:35:36] <cluther> rkagin: For the most part, the intervals are defined at the daemon level. zenperfsnmp cycles every 5 minutes by default, zenstatus and zenping every 1 minute..
[14-Jun-2007 16:36:00] <cluther> rkagin: zencommand is a bit different. Each COMMAND type data source specifies it's own interval and zencommand takes care of the scheduling to keep that contract.
[14-Jun-2007 16:36:24] <cluther> rkagin: You can find most of these interval settings defined in Monitors->(Status|Performance)
[14-Jun-2007 16:39:12] <rkagin> cluther: I appreciate your help. I'm just trying to learn how things get modeled (I think I understand that), and then once they are modeled, how they are monitored, what happens when, and why.
[14-Jun-2007 16:40:51]  <qru> 2007-06-14 09:42:54 Executing command: /opt/zenoss/bin/zendisc run --net=192.168.0.0
[14-Jun-2007 16:41:11]  <qru> 2007-06-14 14:36:42 WARNING:zen.IpRouteEntry:interface index:0 not found
[14-Jun-2007 16:41:23]  <qru> Still going.
[14-Jun-2007 16:43:08]  <cluther> qru: How many entries in your routing table?
[14-Jun-2007 16:44:08]  <qru> ~1000
[14-Jun-2007 16:45:30]  <cluther> qru: Hmm.. go to the zProperties for /Devices/Discovered
[14-Jun-2007 16:45:35]  <cluther> qru: What Zenoss version?
[14-Jun-2007 16:45:51]  <qru> Will that abort the discovery?
[14-Jun-2007 16:46:11]  <cluther> qru: Yes.. I recommend that you abort it.
[14-Jun-2007 16:46:38]  <cluther> qru: SNMP isn't a great protocol for transferring large amounts of information.
[14-Jun-2007 16:46:47]  <cluther> qru: Anything that takes that long in SNMP probably will result in failure.
[14-Jun-2007 16:46:53]  <qru> chug chug
[14-Jun-2007 16:47:31]  <cluther> qru: 2.0?
[14-Jun-2007 16:47:39]  <qru> cluther: Yes. Fresh install.
[14-Jun-2007 16:47:59] <cluther> qru: Once you make it to those zProperties, click Edit for the zCollectorPlugins and remove RouteMap from the list.
[14-Jun-2007 16:48:08]  <cluther> qru: Then try to discover that network again.
[14-Jun-2007 16:49:23]  <Aziraphale> that'd be one for the doc...
[14-Jun-2007 16:50:19]  <Aziraphale> seems I'm not the only one with big routing tables on some routers
[14-Jun-2007 16:51:50]  <cluther> Aziraphale: Definitely not..
[14-Jun-2007 16:52:32]  <cluther> cluther: The way to really fix this would be to write a telnet based route collector.
[14-Jun-2007 16:52:54]  <Aziraphale> cluther: not standardised
[14-Jun-2007 16:53:15]  <Aziraphale> besides, can zeodb handle 450,000 entries ina routing table?
[14-Jun-2007 16:53:35] <cluther> Aziraphale: The idea would be to only "sh ip route ospf" or something so you skip the BGP entries entirely.
[14-Jun-2007 16:53:57]  <Aziraphale> ah, I see

[14-Jun-2007 16:55:06]  <Aziraphale> for refence, the command on a Juniper is show route protocol ospf

[14-Jun-2007 17:01:35] <qru> cluther: Would zenoss try to auto discover other networks that are identified when polling devices on the network I am discovering?
[14-Jun-2007 17:02:08] <cluther> qru: By default, yes. If this doesn't suite you, go the the zProperties for /Networks and set zAutoDiscover to False.
[14-Jun-2007 17:02:25] <cluther> qru: You can then in the future go to specific networks and enable the zAutoDiscover property on them.

[15-Jun-2007 09:26:25]  <creiht> And then my devices show up in the /24 blocks

[15-Jun-2007 09:45:11]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: you around today?
[15-Jun-2007 09:45:47]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: A bit.
[15-Jun-2007 09:46:29]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: have you worked with the WMI portion of 2.0?
[15-Jun-2007 09:46:34]  <cluther> yes
[15-Jun-2007 09:46:56]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: any good docs you have read on setting it up?
[15-Jun-2007 09:49:03]  *** Myweb has left #zenoss
[15-Jun-2007 09:49:53] <giesen> Is there any solution to the "sendto error short format requires 0<=number<=USHRT_MAX" problem?
[15-Jun-2007 09:53:12] <cluther> Bulwinkle: No, that section of the Admin Guide hasn't been filled out yet.. it is very few steps though.
[15-Jun-2007 09:53:36]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: if you have time can you run me through them?
[15-Jun-2007 09:53:40]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Put all of your Windows servers somewhere under /Devices/Server/Windows.
[15-Jun-2007 09:53:48]  <Bulwinkle> Done
[15-Jun-2007 09:53:50]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Create a domain admin account if you have a domain.
[15-Jun-2007 09:54:04]  <Bulwinkle> will a local admin on the box work?
[15-Jun-2007 09:54:17]  <cluther> Yes.. for local admin..
[15-Jun-2007 09:54:23]  <Bulwinkle> done
[15-Jun-2007 09:54:46] <cluther> Bulwinkle: In the zProperties for /Devices/Server/Windows set zWinUsername to ".\Administrator" and set the zWinPassword.
[15-Jun-2007 09:54:56]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Make sure that zWmiMonitorIgnore is set to False.
[15-Jun-2007 09:55:20] <cluther> Bulwinkle: Go the the Settings/Daemons page and verify that zenwinmodeler, zenwin and zeneventlog are running.
[15-Jun-2007 09:55:45] <cluther> cluther: That's it. After about 10 minutes you'll either see WMI errors in your event console, or windows services listed on the OS tab of your Windows server.
[15-Jun-2007 09:56:10] <cluther> Bulwinkle: So the key zProperties for WMI monitoring are zWinUsername, zWinPassword and zWmiMonitorIgnore.
[15-Jun-2007 09:56:41]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: can I use a domain account (which is local admin on the boxes)?
[15-Jun-2007 09:57:48]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Hmm.. I haven't tried it, but I'd guess that it works.
[15-Jun-2007 09:58:04]  <Bulwinkle> We'll see, Thanks...  I'll let you know how it works out!
[15-Jun-2007 09:58:05]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Just format the zWinUsername as "DOMAIN\Username"
[15-Jun-2007 10:00:13]  <cluther> giesen: Does this error occur on many devices, or just the zenoss server itself?
[15-Jun-2007 10:11:08]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: worked flawlessly...  Thanks!
[15-Jun-2007 10:11:30]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: I always like to hear those words. =}
[15-Jun-2007 10:11:52]  <Bulwinkle> cluther:  Should I upgrade from 2.0 b2 to 2.0.0?
[15-Jun-2007 10:12:45]  <cluther> hmm. b2 = 1.9.6?
[15-Jun-2007 10:13:13]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: yeah..  sorry thats what I meant
[15-Jun-2007 10:15:05] <cluther> Bulwinkle: Yeah, go ahead. It is an easy upgrade (no zen2dump/zenload required) and fixes a number of bugs.
[15-Jun-2007 10:15:36] <Bulwinkle> cluther: I'm still having trouble with 3 services starting... let me upgrade and I'll ping back atcha in a few
[15-Jun-2007 10:18:52]  <kompressor> cluther, im still using 1.1.2....is a complete 2.0 reinstall necessary?
[15-Jun-2007 10:19:45]  <cluther> kompressor: There are instructions ZEN2UPGRADE.TXT linked to from the 2.0 release notes.
[15-Jun-2007 10:20:01] <cluther> kompressor: It shows the process to use to dump your object database and import it into 2.0.
[15-Jun-2007 10:21:16]  <kompressor> cluther, thanx :-)
[15-Jun-2007 10:22:30] <cluther> kompressor: FYI to you and others.. use the RPM installation method if at all possible. It makes it so much easier for us to predict good upgrade paths.
[15-Jun-2007 10:23:07]  <kompressor> eish cluther im using ubuntu debs or from source
[15-Jun-2007 10:23:15]  <kompressor> no RPM
[15-Jun-2007 10:23:18]  <cluther> kompressor: Yeah.. no choice for you. =}
[15-Jun-2007 10:24:07] <kompressor> cluther, how far is that feature of "authenticating zenoss via ldap" since 2.0 is just released?
[15-Jun-2007 10:24:40]  <kompressor> just wondering....
[15-Jun-2007 10:25:01]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: looks like they fixed my problem in 2.0.0
[15-Jun-2007 10:26:22] <Bulwinkle> cluther: I'm getting some SNMP errors on my windows servers memoryPagespersec, memoryAvailablekBytes, and cpuPercentProcessorTime...
[15-Jun-2007 10:27:14] <cluther> Bulwinkle: Those are the SNMP Informant polls. You can either install the SNMP Informant MIB extension on your Windows server(s) or remove those data sources from the Device template under /Devices/Server/Windows.
[15-Jun-2007 10:27:48]  <Bulwinkle> cluther:  where would I find that extension?
[15-Jun-2007 10:28:11]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Google "snmp informant" and get the free version.

[15-Jun-2007 10:44:45]  <_zack> hi all, i've a question about the mysql permission set by the zenoss installation
[15-Jun-2007 10:44:50]  <_zack> from install-function.sh I read
[15-Jun-2007 10:44:58] <_zack> grant all on $MYSQLEVENTDB.* to '$MYSQLUSER'@'${MYSQL_HOST_PERM}' identified by '$MYSQLPASS';
[15-Jun-2007 10:44:58]  <_zack>          grant super, file on *.* to '$MYSQLUSER'@'${MYSQL_HOST_PERM}';
[15-Jun-2007 10:45:03]  <_zack> the first line is fine
[15-Jun-2007 10:45:14]  <_zack> but the second seems to me to grant all permissions on all databases to the zenoss user
[15-Jun-2007 10:45:21]  <_zack> is this expected/needed?
[15-Jun-2007 10:48:17] <cluther> _zack: hmm.. those permissions are required for the run_zeneventbuild function to install the triggers. Unfortunately MySQL 5 requires super and file privileges to create triggers.
[15-Jun-2007 10:48:38]  <cluther> _zack: I think the super, file permissions could be removed after the install.
[15-Jun-2007 10:48:51]  <_zack> cluther: ah, ok
[15-Jun-2007 10:48:59]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: are you helping in development (coding) or mainly with support issues?
[15-Jun-2007 10:49:09] <cluther> _zack: I'm not totally sure on this though.. I'm not sure if any special privileges on the mysql database are required to run triggers.
[15-Jun-2007 10:49:18]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: support.
[15-Jun-2007 10:49:29]  <_zack> cluther: i'll check that
[15-Jun-2007 10:49:32]  <_zack> thanks
[15-Jun-2007 10:51:16] <Bulwinkle> cluther: congrats, I haven't found anyone here that knows as much as you... They need the help I know. Once I move my system to production we'll buy a support contract for sure and maybe even go for some training.
[15-Jun-2007 10:52:16]  <creiht> cluther is quite the bundle of zenoss knowledge
[15-Jun-2007 10:52:17]  <cluther> cluther: Great.. I'll probably be part of the training so I look forward to meeting you.
[15-Jun-2007 10:53:13] <_zack> cluther: still, why give them on *.*?, wouldn't it be enough to give them on the zenoss database?
[15-Jun-2007 10:53:19]  <_zack> AFAIK triggers are database-specific
[15-Jun-2007 10:53:54]  <cluther> _zack: You'd think that, but it does something on the mysql database too.
[15-Jun-2007 10:54:26]  <cluther> _zack: We could probably do super,file on mysql.**something**

[15-Jun-2007 14:04:54]  <|__rb__|> hi cluther, it's zen 1.0
[15-Jun-2007 14:05:13] <cluther> |__rb__|: Ethernet interfaces are graphed by default, go to the OS tab and choose one of them.
[15-Jun-2007 14:05:55] <cluther> |__rb__|: To get graphing on you serial interfaces go to the PerfConf tab of /Devices and copy the ethernetCsmacd template, paste it, then rename it to serialPointToPoint.
[15-Jun-2007 14:06:08]  <|__rb__|> AH!!! genious
[15-Jun-2007 14:06:10]  <cluther> |__rb__|: Then restart the zenperfsnmp daemon.
[15-Jun-2007 14:06:35]  <|__rb__|> I was looking in the perf for the graphs
[15-Jun-2007 14:06:38] <cluther> |__rb__|: 2.0 automatically graphs all interface types.. you have to tell it which ones you don't want to graph. I think this makes more sense.
[15-Jun-2007 14:06:52]  <|__rb__|> sure, I will upgrade probably soon
[15-Jun-2007 14:06:56]  <cluther> |__rb__|: You're going to have to get used to things being done the right way.. =}
[15-Jun-2007 14:07:26]  <|__rb__|> nice, thanks cluther

[15-Jun-2007 14:08:09]  <_zack> cluther: uhm, what's the expected behaviour ... nothins is happening here
[15-Jun-2007 14:08:39]  <cluther> _zack: The events should be removed from the event list and put into the "History" list.
[15-Jun-2007 14:26:33]  *** creiht has joined #zenoss
[15-Jun-2007 14:29:55]  <|__rb__|> cluther, is that the same for multilink??
[15-Jun-2007 14:30:39] <cluther> |__rb__|: Interfaces are graphed according to what the template named after their "type" says. If you go into one of your multilink interfaces, what is the type set to?
[15-Jun-2007 14:31:37]  <|__rb__|> type is ppp
[15-Jun-2007 14:31:53]  <cluther> |__rb__|: So you'd just make a copy of that ethernetCsmacd template and name it "ppp"
[15-Jun-2007 14:32:47]  <cluther> |__rb__|: Make sense?
[15-Jun-2007 14:32:58] <|__rb__|> there is alredy a ppp performance template, but it seems empty, should I just copy the ethernetCsmacd and name it ppp?
[15-Jun-2007 14:33:09]  <|__rb__|> yep
[15-Jun-2007 14:33:19]  <cluther> |__rb__|: Yep.. of course you'd have to delete the empty ppp template first.
[15-Jun-2007 14:34:01] <cluther> |__rb__|: If the multilink interface doesn't contains the same OIDs as an ethernetCsmacd interface there may be problems, but I think that they have the same basic OIDs.
[15-Jun-2007 14:34:08]  <|__rb__|> nice
[15-Jun-2007 14:34:09]  <cluther> throughput/packets/errors..
[15-Jun-2007 14:34:41] <cluther> |__rb__|: Once you start to do VLANs and stuff like that you have to remove the error related data sources and graphs from the template since virtual interfaces don't have errors.
[15-Jun-2007 14:34:52]  <|__rb__|> do I need to restart the zenpefsnmp??
[15-Jun-2007 14:37:01] <cluther> |__rb__|: Yeah.. in 1.0 zenperfsnmp only grabs a new config every 20 minutes so impatient people like me just restart it for quicker satisfaction.
[15-Jun-2007 14:37:01]  <cluther> |__rb__|: 2.0 pushes the changes to the collectors on the fly.
[15-Jun-2007 14:37:01]  <|__rb__|> ah, me too
[15-Jun-2007 14:37:01] <|__rb__|> I tried upgrading yesterday..........and an unsuccessfull upgrade, I found the upgrade 1.0 to 2.0 how to
[15-Jun-2007 14:37:01] <cluther> |__rb__|: You'd have to be the luckiest person on earth to manage that without the instructions.
[15-Jun-2007 14:37:18] <cluther> |__rb__|: Most upgrades are very straightforward, but they changes the internal database structure in 2.0 to get some serious performance improvements.

[15-Jun-2007 14:46:00] <cluther> hspcd: Ack'ing an event will make Zenoss send out a CLEAR to anyone who got the original failure alert..

[15-Jun-2007 14:57:14]  <Bulwinkle> How do I create a global alerting rule?
[15-Jun-2007 15:03:53] <cluther> Bulwinkle: What do you mean by that? An alerting rule that alerts on anything going wrong?
[15-Jun-2007 15:04:20]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: one that alerts everyone on a given condition
[15-Jun-2007 15:05:01] <cluther> Bulwinkle: You can't.. you'd have to add the rule to each user. Hold on for a few minutes and I'll give you a tip for getting around this.
[15-Jun-2007 15:05:10]  <Bulwinkle> okay
[15-Jun-2007 15:08:06] <creiht> Bulwinkle: You can create the alert for the user, and then go to the Zope management interface and copy and paste that rule to other users
[15-Jun-2007 15:08:25]  <Bulwinkle> creiht: cool... thanks
[15-Jun-2007 15:08:34]  <creiht> so
[15-Jun-2007 15:08:38]  <creiht> after you add the alert
[15-Jun-2007 15:08:46]  <creiht> open up the user that has that alert
[15-Jun-2007 15:08:50]  <creiht> and then add
[15-Jun-2007 15:08:52]  <creiht>  /manage
[15-Jun-2007 15:08:55]  <creiht> to the end of the url
[15-Jun-2007 15:09:04]  <creiht> you can then check the alert you created
[15-Jun-2007 15:09:06]  <creiht> click copy
[15-Jun-2007 15:09:18]  <creiht> click on ZenUsers in your path at the top
[15-Jun-2007 15:09:31]  <creiht> and then go into each users' folder
[15-Jun-2007 15:09:33]  <creiht> and click paste
[15-Jun-2007 15:10:36]  <Bulwinkle> thats pretty cool
[15-Jun-2007 15:11:50] <creiht> I have a ticket in for them to have something like that where you can define alerts, and then assign users to those alerts
[15-Jun-2007 15:12:08]  <creiht> And I have bugged them several times about it
[15-Jun-2007 15:12:22]  <creiht> I can understand though how it is probably a lower priority
[15-Jun-2007 15:12:55]  <creiht> That workaround works fairly well though until they do something like that
[15-Jun-2007 15:13:20] <creiht> One thing to keep in mind is that if you change one after you have copied and paste, you will either have to copy and paste again, or change all the others as well
[15-Jun-2007 15:13:22] <Bulwinkle> I'd like to enter a feature where you can change the monitoring state to "true" for all of the services checked in the OS tab
[15-Jun-2007 15:13:49]  <Bulwinkle> creiht: I see

[18-Jun-2007 11:51:07]  *** zombor has joined #zenoss
[18-Jun-2007 12:16:04] <rkagin> Once you install ZenOSS, where are the default templates used to determine which devices get queried in certain ways (i.e. certain data is collected)? I'm currently in $ZENHOME/perf/Devices/, but only see the devices I loaded, and pickles inside (I assume the pickles are used to instantiate what sort of data is collected from each of the devices).
[18-Jun-2007 12:24:12]  <cluther_> rkagin: You're looking for the Templates tab for devices or device classes.
[18-Jun-2007 12:28:23]  *** mrhinkle has joined #zenoss
[18-Jun-2007 12:29:15] <rkagin> cluther_: I guess I don't understand: how does ZenOSS set up the default template? Is there not a file that says only run zenping on the device or run zencommand and zenping or whatever else?
[18-Jun-2007 12:30:09] <cluther_> rkagin: No, there aren't any files that say that. Everything is controlled via the templates assigned to the devices and zProperties.
[18-Jun-2007 12:30:40] <cluther_> rkagin: The template assigned to a device depends on what device class you have put it in.
[18-Jun-2007 12:31:09] <cluther_> rkagin: For example, a device in /Devices/Server/Linux will have a template applied to it that queries the Net-SNMP MIB.
[18-Jun-2007 12:31:28] <rkagin> cluther_: But the very first time, when there are no devices, and you load your first device in, how does it know what sort of checks are done on it?
[18-Jun-2007 12:31:30] <cluther_> rkagin: Where as a device put into /Devices/Network/Router/Cisco will have Cisco specific OIDS monitored.
[18-Jun-2007 12:31:49] <cluther_> rkagin: There are default templates pre-loaded into different points in the device class hierarchy.
[18-Jun-2007 12:32:06]  <rkagin> cluther_: Where are these pre-loaded templates located in the code?
[18-Jun-2007 12:32:10]  <cluther_> rkagin: You can use them as-is, take example from them, or a mixture of the two..
[18-Jun-2007 12:32:28]  *** crazyal has joined #zenoss
[18-Jun-2007 12:33:04] <rkagin> cluther_: My /Devices directory only contains the devices I have loaded, and that's it - there's no sub-directories (because I haven't loaded devices in them?). Are you saying that these subdirectory templates already exist somewhere else?
[18-Jun-2007 12:33:12] <cluther_> rkagin: They are loaded from XML. If you really want to see them in this form for some reason, take a look in the $ZENHOME/Products/ZenModel/data directory.
[18-Jun-2007 12:33:42]  <cluther_> rkagin: You should have things like /Network, /Server, /Power located under /Devices.
[18-Jun-2007 12:33:47]  *** r5 has joined #zenoss
[18-Jun-2007 12:33:50]  <cluther_> rkagin: If you don't, your installation didn't complete successfully.
[18-Jun-2007 12:35:05] <rkagin> Well currently I don't 100% control the installation, but right now I don't have access to the web-interface of zenoss, only ssh'ing into it.
[18-Jun-2007 12:36:55] <rkagin> In $ZENHOME/perf/Devices/, the directory only contains directories for each device (which contains a pickle file). There are no other directories like /Network, /Server, etc. However, when I snuck a preview at the web interface, I am pretty sure I saw the folders existing.
[18-Jun-2007 12:37:07]  <rkagin> By any chance, is this a small change between 1.9.7 and 2.0.0?
[18-Jun-2007 12:37:19]  <creiht> rkagin: Those two things are totally different
[18-Jun-2007 12:37:30]  <creiht> The web interface is totally separate of what you see on disk
[18-Jun-2007 12:37:51]  <creiht> You are not really going to be able to see much of anything through a terminal
[18-Jun-2007 12:38:23] <creiht> The devices are organized in the web interface, and that is also where you will be able to see the templates
[18-Jun-2007 12:39:10] <rkagin> creiht: Fair enough. I guess I should just think of my next question and you'll answer it without seeing it (which has happened for the other two questions I typed out and almost asked).

[18-Jun-2007 13:47:26] <rkagin> For anyone familiar with the templates, what's the difference between the default performance template OSProcess in /Devices (the CPU utilization monitor) and the default template Device in /Devices/Server (the CPU utilization monitor)? If some device is in /Devices/Server, is this just a duplicate monitor of the same information?
[18-Jun-2007 13:47:42]  <_chris__> Dislo: what happens when you run "echo $ZENHOME"?
[18-Jun-2007 13:48:08]  <Dislo> nothing it is a blank line
[18-Jun-2007 13:48:15]  <_chris__> Dislo: that's a problem
[18-Jun-2007 13:48:33]  <_chris__> Dislo: do you have a ~/.bashrc or ~/.bash_profile that sets ZENHOME?
[18-Jun-2007 13:48:52]  <_chris__> looks like you're running as root
[18-Jun-2007 13:48:53]  <Dislo> no i just exported it into path i will go fix that
[18-Jun-2007 13:48:58]  <_chris__> you should be running as the zenoss user
[18-Jun-2007 13:49:01]  <_chris__> zenoss doesn't need root
[18-Jun-2007 13:49:15] <_chris__> for root stuff it uses a single setuid root program (zensocket) to do it's root business.
[18-Jun-2007 13:50:40]  <Dislo> ok
[18-Jun-2007 13:51:37]  <Aziraphale> rkagin: hmm, there are no oids in OsProcess, chances are it does bugger all
[18-Jun-2007 13:52:13]  <rkagin> Aziraphale: So is the /Devices/Server check on CPU utilization a duplicate of the data?
[18-Jun-2007 13:55:03]  *** switchfox has joined #zenoss
[18-Jun-2007 13:55:18]  <Dislo> _chris__, do i need to set anything up with zensocket or is it already taken care of
[18-Jun-2007 13:55:21]  <Aziraphale> duplicate of which data?
[18-Jun-2007 13:55:27]  <joshb> Dislo: its already taken care of..
[18-Jun-2007 13:55:43]  <Dislo> joshb, thanks
[18-Jun-2007 13:56:36] <rkagin> Aziraphale: /Devices/OSProcess collects CPU utilization, and /Devices/Server/Device collects CPU utilization as well. Is there a difference in this data, given that a device in /Devices/Server would have both templates acting on it?
[18-Jun-2007 13:57:28]  <Aziraphale> OSProcess collects nothing, it has no OIDs
[18-Jun-2007 13:57:53] <cluther> Aziraphale: OSProcess is a special template handled by the zenprocess daemon. It does collect per-process CPU utilization and memory usage.
[18-Jun-2007 13:58:16] <cluther> rkagin: The data isn't duplicate.. OSProcess is per-process utilization, Device is for the whole OS.
[18-Jun-2007 13:58:26]  <Aziraphale> cluther: where's the data coming from, without OISs?
[18-Jun-2007 13:58:30]  <Aziraphale> OIDs even
[18-Jun-2007 13:58:48] <cluther> Aziraphale: The zenprocess daemons knows what the OIDs are, and has some specific logic to handle changing PIDs, etc..
[18-Jun-2007 13:59:04]  <Aziraphale> cluther: oh, ok
[18-Jun-2007 13:59:36] <rkagin> cluther: Is this same delineation made between OSProcess and the Device template in /Network/Router/Cisco ?

[19-Jun-2007 11:00:40]  <creiht> bzed: I've had similar problems on another monitoring system
[19-Jun-2007 11:00:51]  <creiht> And it is usually due to bad network configs
[19-Jun-2007 11:01:40] <creiht> Things like having the netmask set incorrectly, or having odd routes that send outgoing traffic through another interface
[19-Jun-2007 11:01:58]  <creiht> command line ping is a bit more forgiving
[19-Jun-2007 11:02:07]  <creiht> in these types of circumstances
[19-Jun-2007 11:02:25]  <creiht> Also bad NAT configs
[19-Jun-2007 11:09:21]  <Aziraphale> whoah, icmp UNREACH packets are not bad network config
[19-Jun-2007 11:09:42]  <Aziraphale> the downstream router from an unreachable host is supposed to send them
[19-Jun-2007 11:10:13]  <Aziraphale> (if the host *is* unreachable that is)

[19-Jun-2007 11:48:32]  <Aziraphale> ~ah
[19-Jun-2007 11:48:41]  <Aziraphale> I've seen that happen with VPN connections
[19-Jun-2007 11:49:07]  <Aziraphale> ping returns from the *outside* interface where you ping the *inside* one

[20-Jun-2007 02:47:22] <freakynl> we already looked at nagios 3 years ago and i'm kind of sorry to see not much has changed on the exterior. Our main issues are it's hard to configure for non-linux admins and it can't be done through the webinterface, it looks ugly (yes, it's functional, but ppl like our managers will actually look away because of this), and it lacks 'real' support for snmp traps and graphing images for bandwidth and such (yes this can be done with other too
[20-Jun-2007 02:54:06] <kompressor> freakynl, i've used nagios for the past year and currently evaluating zenoss...yes nagios works though

[20-Jun-2007 13:30:59] <rkagin> zombor: In the performance graphs, you can choose daily, weekly, monthly, or even yearly. From there, you can choose to zoom in on certain parts or zoom out from your current view.
[20-Jun-2007 13:31:50]  <zombor> but it it monthly from today, or monthly from the first of the month?
[20-Jun-2007 13:32:58] <rkagin> zombor: The view does not do aggregate by monthly - rather, it zooms out until you view the monthly view.
[20-Jun-2007 13:33:21] <rkagin> zombor: I'm sure you could fidget around to create a graph that graphs aggregate use over the course of a month or whatever you would like to see.

[21-Jun-2007 13:00:09] <rkagin> s34n: ZenOSS is network monitoring software, not network administrative software. My understanding is that it's supposed to automate the watching process, and when something fails or whatever, then you can get an email or alert. It allows you to analyze how your system has been used in the past through several different performance features, etc. ZenPacks will allow you to add custom features to it, and export it to a package that you could hand off t

[22-Jun-2007 10:41:43]  <tty01> snmpwalk the device i mean

[22-Jun-2007 10:42:13]  <creiht> Check that you are using the correct snmp community string
[22-Jun-2007 10:42:18]  <tty01> strings right
[22-Jun-2007 10:42:22]  <creiht> and that the device is allowing snmp connections from your server
[22-Jun-2007 10:42:31]  <tty01> its loaded on a older zenoss box
[22-Jun-2007 10:42:36]  <tty01> and i can walk it
[22-Jun-2007 10:42:48]  <tty01> i copied over the same MIB file to the newer zenoss box
[22-Jun-2007 10:43:09]  <creiht> are you talkinga bout an snmpwalk from the command line?
[22-Jun-2007 10:43:29]  <tty01> well if i cant walk it, then zenoss wont be able to discover it either
[22-Jun-2007 10:43:50]  <tty01> am i doing it wrong to load it into the box?
[22-Jun-2007 10:44:15]  <creiht> As far as I understand, doing a basic snmpwalk doesn't need any mibs loaded
[22-Jun-2007 10:44:26]  <tty01> community string is definitely right
[22-Jun-2007 10:44:44]  <creiht> is the device a server, or some type of networking device?
[22-Jun-2007 10:44:53]  <tty01> network device
[22-Jun-2007 10:45:03]  <tty01> one of our main routers
[22-Jun-2007 10:45:12]  <creiht> Did you have access to look at its configs?
[22-Jun-2007 10:45:22]  <tty01> that i dont =\
[22-Jun-2007 10:45:31]  <creiht> doh
[22-Jun-2007 10:45:39]  <tty01> actually i think i do
[22-Jun-2007 10:45:58]  <creiht> If you can, check the snmp config to make sure it allows your zenoss ip to access snmp
[22-Jun-2007 10:46:01]  <creiht> my guess is it limits it to a select number of ips
[22-Jun-2007 10:46:08]  <creiht> most places do this for security reasons
[22-Jun-2007 10:46:46]  <tty01> ah ok i see it now
[22-Jun-2007 10:46:54]  <tty01> it was sending traps to only the older zenoss box
[22-Jun-2007 10:47:25]  <creiht> ok
[22-Jun-2007 10:47:34]  <creiht> and for traps you will need the mibs loaded
[22-Jun-2007 10:47:39]  <creiht> to correctly identify thme
[22-Jun-2007 10:48:02]  <creiht> there are two pieces of snmp though
[22-Jun-2007 10:48:06]  <tty01> yeah i thought the mib had to be loaded, even for a walk
[22-Jun-2007 10:48:12]  <creiht> nah
[22-Jun-2007 10:48:25]  <creiht> the mibs are only used when zenoss receives a trap
[22-Jun-2007 10:48:44]  <creiht> At least as far as I understand
[22-Jun-2007 10:49:00]  <tty01> works now
[22-Jun-2007 10:49:00]  <creiht> cool
[22-Jun-2007 10:49:00]  <tty01> thank you sir!
[22-Jun-2007 10:49:29]  <tty01> anyway for me to add device and specify the ip for it?
[22-Jun-2007 10:50:01]  <creiht> yeah
[22-Jun-2007 10:50:07]  <creiht> Open up the web ui
[22-Jun-2007 10:50:26]  <tty01> k
[22-Jun-2007 10:50:26]  <creiht> and in the menu on the left, there should be an add device option
[22-Jun-2007 10:50:27]  <tty01> yeah im there now
[22-Jun-2007 10:50:49]  <creiht> put the ip in of the device, choose where you want in the device heirarchy, the community string, and any other options you want
[22-Jun-2007 10:51:01]  <creiht> And then click the button
[22-Jun-2007 10:52:26]  <tty01> what if i want to specify it by name instead of ip?....zenoss wont add it since its not a actual entry in dns
[22-Jun-2007 10:52:56]  <tty01> discovery protocol is already set to none

[22-Jun-2007 11:03:01]  <moredakka> creiht, you said you haven't used zenwin before right?
[22-Jun-2007 11:07:55]  <Bulwinkle> can anyone tell me how easy it will be to move a configuration running on one system (development) to another (production)?
[22-Jun-2007 11:08:23]  <Bulwinkle> moredakka: do you have questions with zenwin?  I have it running quite nicely
[22-Jun-2007 11:15:22]  <moredakka> yeah, I'm just not sure on how it acutally works.  Does zenwin have to be installed on all the windows devices that are being monitored or does it get installed on another "zenoss server" that has an instance of windows then the main zenoss box polls from that one windows box?
[22-Jun-2007 11:23:05]  *** bzed has joined #zenoss
[22-Jun-2007 11:27:11]  <moredakka> omg I %100 wish there was a dev around...
[22-Jun-2007 11:29:53]  <Bulwinkle> moredakka: zenoss now uses SAMBA to poll windows.  You don't need to install daemons on the windows servers any longer.
[22-Jun-2007 11:35:16]  <creiht> moredakka: As far as I know is that it talks directly through WMI, so you just have ZenWin installed on a zenoss box which polls WMI on the windows servers.  I believe that it does require a user on the box with certain rights to be able to read the WMI
[22-Jun-2007 11:37:57]  <Bulwinkle> creiht: definitely...  You provide the administrator (local to server) account to zenoss and it polls the server through WMI....  It has worked flawlessly so far.
[22-Jun-2007 11:41:24]  <moredakka> Ok but currently I'm using 1.1.1, the zenwin deamon would ahve to be installed on those servers to get all the OIDs to respond properly?
[22-Jun-2007 11:41:54]  <moredakka> The problem right now is, we don't have access to install extra agents and the company that we do monitoring for will not allow it.
[22-Jun-2007 11:41:56]  <creiht> moredakka:
[22-Jun-2007 11:41:57]  <creiht> err
[22-Jun-2007 11:41:59]  <creiht> hehe
[22-Jun-2007 11:42:00]  <creiht> no
[22-Jun-2007 11:42:29]  <creiht> on the old version you have to have ZenWin running on one windows machine that would then poll the other servers
[22-Jun-2007 11:43:03]  <moredakka> Zenoss isn't reporting cpu usage and a couple other things on the windows boxes unless there is an agent or something like that installed on the windows machine
[22-Jun-2007 11:43:04]  <Bulwinkle> moredakka: I'd highly recommend upgrading...  there are step-by-step instructions on www.zenoss.com
[22-Jun-2007 11:43:12]  <creiht> I'm not sure if the rest of the Zenoss has to be running on the windows box
[22-Jun-2007 11:43:25]  <Bulwinkle> moredakka: the snmp extender does have to be installed...  Its not an agent though.
[22-Jun-2007 11:44:01]  <moredakka> I just can't remember the name...starts with an 'i'... :-/

[22-Jun-2007 16:47:39]  <tty01> anyone know snmp real well?

[22-Jun-2007 16:48:21]  <tty01> i have a oid.....its supposedly the oid for client connections....how can i be sure?
[22-Jun-2007 16:48:51]  <KnckrBckr> creight: thanks - i will rtfm and come back - likely with more questions
[22-Jun-2007 16:48:54]  <creiht> tty01: You can run the command line command snmpget with the oid
[22-Jun-2007 16:49:04]  <creiht> KnckrBckr: no problem... good luck
[22-Jun-2007 16:49:12]  <creiht> Not completely sure the syntax
[22-Jun-2007 16:49:18]  <creiht> probably something like
[22-Jun-2007 16:49:25]  <MNSain> Knckbckr:  Good luck.  See you around.
[22-Jun-2007 16:49:42]  <creiht> snmpget -cCommunityString ip_address OID
[22-Jun-2007 16:49:46]  <MNSain> creiht: He could snmpwalk it, too.
[22-Jun-2007 16:49:49]  <creiht> yeah
[22-Jun-2007 16:50:04]  <moredakka> creiht: what's the snmpwalk command to get all the oids from a system?
[22-Jun-2007 16:50:04]  <tty01> i walked it and it doesnt give me a definite answer
[22-Jun-2007 16:50:06]  <creiht> Sorry I don't know the exact syntax... but something like snmpget --help should get you pretty far
[22-Jun-2007 16:50:25]  <creiht> snmpwalk -cCommunityString -v1 ip_address
[22-Jun-2007 16:50:35]  <moredakka> excellent...thnx
[22-Jun-2007 16:50:57]  <moredakka> if I have rw on the server that won't try to write anything, will it?
[22-Jun-2007 16:51:19]  <tty01> a walk doesnt write anything

[27-Jun-2007 10:27:58]  <tty01> anyone know how to fix ERROR zen.zencommand: [Errno 24] Too many open files
[27-Jun-2007 10:30:19]  <rave182> what os are you running tty01?
[27-Jun-2007 10:30:25]  <tty01> rhel 4
[27-Jun-2007 10:30:55]  <rave182> in rhel you can configure the amount of open files for a user in /etc/security/limits.conf
[27-Jun-2007 10:31:18]  <tty01> hmm lemme check the limits
[27-Jun-2007 10:31:53]  <rave182> http://bcr2.uwaterloo.ca/~brecht/servers/openfiles.html
[27-Jun-2007 10:31:53]  <adytum-bot> Title: Linux: Increasing the number of open file descriptors (at bcr2.uwaterloo.ca)
[27-Jun-2007 10:31:53]  <rave182> check that link
[27-Jun-2007 10:32:12]  <rave182> thank you bot
[27-Jun-2007 10:32:12]  <tty01> yeah thats the link i used yesterday
[27-Jun-2007 10:32:14]  <tty01> hehe
[27-Jun-2007 10:32:59]  <tty01> cat /proc/sys/fs/file-max
[27-Jun-2007 10:32:59]  <tty01> 65535
[27-Jun-2007 10:33:24]  <rave182> wwhat user are you running zen as?
[27-Jun-2007 10:33:29]  <tty01> zenoss
[27-Jun-2007 10:34:08]  <tty01> argh and no limit binary
[27-Jun-2007 10:35:19]  <rave182> ulimit
[27-Jun-2007 10:35:43]  <rave182> as the user zenoss type ulimit -a
[27-Jun-2007 10:35:55]  <rave182> should tell you the amount of open files the user can have
[27-Jun-2007 10:36:02]  <rave182> open files                      (-n) 1024
[27-Jun-2007 10:36:03]  <tty01> open files                      (-n) 1024
[27-Jun-2007 10:36:42]  <rave182> open files                      (-n) 65536
[27-Jun-2007 10:36:47]  <rave182> that's so much cooler
[27-Jun-2007 10:37:05]  <tty01> yes i am envious
[27-Jun-2007 10:37:08]  <rave182> lol
[27-Jun-2007 10:37:16]  <tty01> how do i increase it as zenoss user?
[27-Jun-2007 10:37:41]  <rave182> something in /etc/security/limits.conf
[27-Jun-2007 10:38:08]  <tty01> *                soft    nofile          65535
[27-Jun-2007 10:38:08]  <tty01> *                hard    nofile          65535
[27-Jun-2007 10:38:12]  <tty01> is that right syntax?
[27-Jun-2007 10:38:17]  <tty01> i had to add those in manually
[27-Jun-2007 10:38:37]  <rave182> yeah that should do it for all users
[27-Jun-2007 10:38:47]  <tty01> what process needs to be restarted?
[27-Jun-2007 10:38:53]  <tty01> in order for the change to get picked up
[27-Jun-2007 10:39:00]  <rave182> exit out of the zenoss user and su back in
[27-Jun-2007 10:39:07]  <rave182> check your ulimit to see if it increased
[27-Jun-2007 10:39:48]  <tty01> open files                      (-n) 65535

[27-Jun-2007 14:42:02]  <tty01> so just vi /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf
[27-Jun-2007 14:42:12]  <tty01> enter exec /bin/sh /pathtoyourscript
[27-Jun-2007 14:42:45]  <tty01> then you can do a snmpwalk -v1 hostname -c communitystring UCD-SNMP-MIB::extOutput.1
[27-Jun-2007 14:42:50]  <tty01> and search for the value
[27-Jun-2007 14:42:56]  <tty01> brb

[27-Jun-2007 15:10:53]  <tty01> copy and paste what you put into your snmpd.conf
[27-Jun-2007 15:16:28]  <soloman> exec zen_test /usr/local/bin/zenoss_test
[27-Jun-2007 15:16:57]  <soloman> and zenoss_test is #!/bin/bash
[27-Jun-2007 15:16:58]  <soloman> echo 45
[27-Jun-2007 15:19:02]  <tty01> you sure you're checking the right OID
[27-Jun-2007 15:19:38]  <soloman> how can I find out what OID is right?
[27-Jun-2007 15:20:37]  <tty01> do the walk again....but add enterprises.ucdavis.extTable.extEntry to the end this time
[27-Jun-2007 15:20:51]  <tty01> see if the value you're looking for shows up there
[27-Jun-2007 15:21:16]  <soloman> snmpwalk -v 1 localhost -c public enterprises.ucdavis.extTable.extEntry
[27-Jun-2007 15:21:16]  <soloman> UCD-SNMP-MIB::extIndex.1 = INTEGER: 1
[27-Jun-2007 15:21:16]  <soloman> UCD-SNMP-MIB::extNames.1 = STRING: zen_test
[27-Jun-2007 15:21:16]  <soloman> UCD-SNMP-MIB::extCommand.1 = STRING: /usr/local/bin/zenoss_test
[27-Jun-2007 15:21:16]  <soloman> UCD-SNMP-MIB::extResult.1 = INTEGER: 45
[27-Jun-2007 15:21:17]  <soloman> UCD-SNMP-MIB::extOutput.1 = STRING: TestDP=45
[27-Jun-2007 15:21:19]  <soloman> UCD-SNMP-MIB::extErrFix.1 = INTEGER: 0
[27-Jun-2007 15:21:21]  <soloman> UCD-SNMP-MIB::extErrFixCmd.1 = STRING:
[27-Jun-2007 15:27:39]  <tty01> do a snmptranslate -Td -On UCD-SNMP-MIB::extResult.1
[27-Jun-2007 15:27:44]  <tty01> and thats the OID you do the check for
[27-Jun-2007 15:30:48]  <soloman> great seems to be the right OID thank you
[27-Jun-2007 15:31:31]  <soloman> but it still doesn't collect data from this script

[29-Jun-2007 10:11:21]  <Bulwinkle> Anyone know how I can differentiate between VLANs and PortChannels in CiscoIOS?
[29-Jun-2007 10:12:31]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: They're both of type "propVirtual" right?
[29-Jun-2007 10:13:14]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: Unfortunately yes....  I want to collect stats for the portchannels but the VLANs keep on throwing back SNMP errors on the OIDs
[29-Jun-2007 10:14:16]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: The only way to do it would be to cause them to be a different type. This could be done in the InterfaceMap data collector plugin. Let me show you what I mean..
[29-Jun-2007 10:14:42]  *** moredakka has quit IRC
[29-Jun-2007 10:14:53]  * Bulwinkle is watching
[29-Jun-2007 10:15:27]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: 2.x?
[29-Jun-2007 10:15:47]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: yeppers
[29-Jun-2007 10:16:03]  <cluther> Great, we'll make it a ZenPack.
[29-Jun-2007 10:16:32]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Go to Settings/ZenPacks and add a new one. Call it whatever you want.. MyCustomPack or something.
[29-Jun-2007 10:17:24]  <Bulwinkle> okie
[29-Jun-2007 10:17:51]  <soloman> Hi! Can someone help me? I have an SNMP directive 'exec' which run an application and pass it's output to Zenoss. The output looks like: UCD-SNMP-MIB::extOutput.1 = STRING: 55
[29-Jun-2007 10:18:27]  <soloman> but zenoss can't parse thresholds and build graphs for this value because it's a string while zenoss expect INTEGER
[29-Jun-2007 10:19:06]  <soloman> how can I make zenoss understand the extOutput values?
[29-Jun-2007 10:19:11]  <cluther> soloman: You'll need to use Net-SNMP's "pass" or "pass_persist" instead of exec if you want integers.
[29-Jun-2007 10:19:34]  <soloman> cluther: one minutes I'll give a try
[29-Jun-2007 10:19:46]  <cluther> soloman: Check out the SNMP::Persist module on CPAN for an easy way to do this with Perl.
[29-Jun-2007 10:19:54]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: So you have that empty ZenPack now?
[29-Jun-2007 10:20:18]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: yeppers
[29-Jun-2007 10:20:45]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Now see if you have a directory called $ZENHOME/Products/MyCustomPack
[29-Jun-2007 10:20:50]  <soloman> cluther: and how can I find MIB for this value then?
[29-Jun-2007 10:21:33]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: Its there
[29-Jun-2007 10:23:41]  <cluther> soloman: You make it up. If your organization already has an enterprise MIB number assignment you should put it there.
[29-Jun-2007 10:23:56]  <cluther> soloman: Otherwise you could use the extension point on the NetSNMP MIB.. looking that up..
[29-Jun-2007 10:26:44]  <soloman> my organisation doesn't have any enterprise MIB number assignments
[29-Jun-2007 10:26:52]  <cluther> soloman: Somewhere on the UCD experimental branch would be good: 1.3.6.1.4.1.2021.13.??
[29-Jun-2007 10:27:40]  <cluther> soloman: Check out http://support.ipmonitor.com/mibs_byoidtree.aspx?oid=1.3.6.1.4.1.2021.13#h to see what's available.
[29-Jun-2007 10:27:40]  <adytum-bot> Title: ipMonitor Support Portal :: Mibs (at support.ipmonitor.com)
[29-Jun-2007 10:27:42]  <cluther> soloman: It looks like only 1, 14, 15 and 16 are taken so far.
[29-Jun-2007 10:27:58]  <cluther> soloman: So you could grab 1.3.6.1.4.1.2021.13.100 or something like that.
[29-Jun-2007 10:28:27]  <soloman> cluther: ok and how can I set this MIB to my script?
[29-Jun-2007 10:29:00]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: ok, great.. there should be a directory within it called modelers/plugins
[29-Jun-2007 10:29:41]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: got them
[29-Jun-2007 10:29:55]  <cluther> soloman: The SNMP::Persist module explains how to set the base OID in the docs: http://search.cpan.org/~anias/SNMP-Persist-0.05/lib/SNMP/Persist.pm
[29-Jun-2007 10:29:55]  <adytum-bot> Title: SNMP::Persist - The SNMP pass_persist threaded backend - search.cpan.org (at search.cpan.org)
[29-Jun-2007 10:30:01]  <soloman> cluther: ok thank you very much
[29-Jun-2007 10:30:49]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: What you want to do is copy the stock InterfaceMap plugin to your zenpack so you can modify it. So cp $ZENHOME/Products/DataCollector/plugins/zenoss/snmp/InterfaceMap.py to $ZENHOME/Products/MyCustomPack/modeler/plugins/CustomInterfaceMap.py
[29-Jun-2007 10:32:50]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: alrighty
[29-Jun-2007 10:32:56]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: done that
[29-Jun-2007 10:33:19]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Now edit that new CustomInterfaceMap.py file.
[29-Jun-2007 10:33:59]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: okie dokie, got it in nano
[29-Jun-2007 10:34:02]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: First thing is to replace all mentions of InterfaceMap with CustomInterfaceMap. The class needs renamed.. docs, etc.
[29-Jun-2007 10:35:26]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: will a global search and replace take care of it?
[29-Jun-2007 10:36:06]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Yup. After that you'll need to change the "maptype =" part near line 35 back to InterfaceMap. That's the only one that doesn't need changed.
[29-Jun-2007 10:37:02]  <Bulwinkle> cluther: alright, global replace ...  CHECK, maptype change back ... CHECK
[29-Jun-2007 10:37:42]  *** moredakka has joined #zenoss
[29-Jun-2007 10:37:56]  <cluther> Bulwinkle: Now to make the real change. Somewhere around line 134 you'll find: om.type = self.ifTypes.get(str(om.type), "Unknown")
[29-Jun-2007 10:38:09]  *** moredakka has quit IRC
